          performance.mark('gtm.start');
          (function (w, d, s, l, i) {
            w[l] = w[l] || [];
            w[l].push({ 'gtm.start': new Date().getTime(), event: 'gtm.js' });
            var f = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0],
                j = d.createElement(s),
                dl = l != 'dataLayer' ? '&l=' + l : '';
            j.async = true;
            j.src = 'https://www.googletagmanager.com/gtm.js?id=' + i + dl;
            j.onload = function () {
              performance.mark('gtm.end');
              performance.measure('gtm', 'gtm.start', 'gtm.end');
            };
            f.parentNode.insertBefore(j, f);
        })(window, document, 'script', 'dataLayer', 'GTM-M36RG8PT');

Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. \r\n \r\nDuring this CrowdCast, you will learn SlideshowScreen_withSections__cJqYu"><!--$--><div class="metadata Metadata_root__oCstk" data-cy="metadata"><h1 class="Heading_heading__3MAvZ Heading_h1__3k7S2 title Title_root__svkHQ">CrowdCasts Monthly: You Have an Adversary Problem</h1><div class="stats Stats_root__p_BoZ"><time dateTime="2013-10-16 14:09:38 UTC">Oct 16, 2013</time><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">6 likes</span><span class="Stats_bullet__DbT30"></span><span class="Text_root__is73U Text_weight-strong__yEO2S Text_secondary__EPWj0 Text_medium__rk8Tn Likes_root__WVQ1_ text" style="-webkit-line-clamp:0" tabindex="0">21,308<!-- --> <!-- -->views</span></div><div class="author Author_root___6Bx5"><a data-cy="author-link" class="Author_link___lVxw ellipsis" title="CrowdStrike" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike"><div class="Avatar_root__GNWHY" style="width:24px;height:24px;line-height:24px"><img class="Avatar_image__Bbtll" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/profile-photo-CrowdStrike-48x48.jpg?cb=1523357406" alt="CrowdStrike" loading="lazy" decoding="sync"/></div><span>CrowdStrike</span></a></div><div class="description Description_root__kt4uq Description_clamped__PaV_1"><div class="Description_wrapper__hYE9_" data-cy="document-description"><p>You Have an Adversary Problem. Who&#x27;s Targeting You and Why? 
 
Nation-States, Hacktivists, Industrial Spies, and Organized Criminal Groups are attacking your enterprise on a daily basis. Their goals range from espionage for technology advancement and disruption of critical infrastructure to for-profit theft of trade secrets and supporting a political agenda. You no longer have a malware problem, you have an adversary problem, and you must incorporate an intelligence-driven approach to your security strategy. 
 
During this CrowdCast, you will learn how to:

    Incorporate Actionable Intelligence into your existing enterprise security infrastructure 
    Quickly understand the capabilities and artifacts of targeted attacked tradecraft 
    Gain insight into the motivations and intentions of targeted attackers
    Make informed decisions based off of specific threat intelligence

less"><span>Read less</span></button></p></div><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_primary__K25Gq Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Description_more__ChrRK"  " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-3-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide4" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-3" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Today’s Speakers
MATT DAHL |
SENIOR ANALYST/ LEGAL COUNSEL

specific adversary activity

4

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-4-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide5" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-4" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Adversaries are humans
Targeted Attackers:

WHO ARE THE
ADVERSARIES?

Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
They need to get in
They will likely need to move laterally

Spray and Pray (Prey):
They don’t care who they target
(sometimes what)
The more they compromise the
more they win
Motivation can range from disruption,
theft, to even destruction
2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

Adversary Categorization
CATEGORIZATION| Adversary Groups

1

Tactics, Techniques, and Practices

2

Never assume relationships exist
Between indicators

3

Recognize adversaries are constantly changing

4

But RECOGNIZE they are HUMAN

CATEGORIZATION

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-17-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide18" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-17" alt="@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Target Sectors: Aerospace; Defense;
Energy; Government; Shipping;
Technology; Telecommunications

WHO IS
GOBLIN PANDA?

Delivery: Spearphishing
Malware: HttpTunnel (AV detection = Zegost)
Mutexes: HttpTunnel@@ or Http@@@

C2 Indicators: vnpt.conimes.com;
mofa.conimes.com;
pvep.scvhosts.com; 112.175.79.55;
223.26.55.122; 198.100.97.245

1

INTELLIGENCE

Understand the adversaries targeting your
Vertical | Company | Geo-Location | Customers

2

Build appropriate defenses to counter/detect
these adversaries

3

Perform other security practices from an
Adversary-centric perspective
Pen Testing (Red Team)
Security Operations Brieﬁngs
Log Review

INTELLIGENCE-DRIVEN SECURITY
INTELLIGENCE| Making it Actionable

1
ACTIONALIZING INTELLIGENCE

Intelligence is diﬃcult to consume
Lots of information to keep straight
New data constantly ﬂowing in (possibly unvetted)

2

Security Operations need to change shis &amp; people

3

Actionable Intelligence

Pass down can’t possibly occur with all indicators

2013 Crowdstrike, Inc. All rights reserved.

 " class="vertical-slide-image VerticalSlideImage_image__VtE4p" data-testid="vertical-slide-image" fetchpriority="auto" loading="lazy" srcSet="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-320.jpg 320w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-638.jpg 638w, https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/75/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-2048.jpg 2048w" src="https://image.slidesharecdn.com/crowdcastsmonthlyyouhaveanadversaryproblem-131016140939-phpapp01/85/CrowdCasts-Monthly-You-Have-an-Adversary-Problem-33-320.jpg" sizes="100vw"/></div><!--$--><!--/$--></div></div><div><div id="slide34" class="VerticalSlide_root__jU_9r slide-item" style="aspect-ratio:959 / 540" data-cy="slide-container"><div class="VerticalSlideImage_root__64KSA"><img id="slide-image-33" alt="Q&amp;A

Q&amp;A

@CROWDSTRIKE | #CROWDCASTS

Please type all questions into the
Q&amp;A section of the
GoToWebinar Control Panel

At crowdcasts@crowdstrike.com

slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Summiting the Pyramid of Pain: Operationalizing ATT&amp;CK,...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Summiting the Pyramid of Pain: Operationalizing ATT&amp;CK,... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Operationalizing the ATT&amp;CK framework has enabled GE to deploy custom detection to evolving threat actor behaviors. By leveraging an in-house developed tool called TIAMAT (Tactical Intelligence Adversary Mapping and Analysis Tool) the ATT&amp;CK framework is
incorporated into an end-to-end operational process from intelligence collection to customized detection deployment. 

The designing of this new operational process is examined, and a use case presented of how examining a historical incident led to a new method of deploying detection based on ATT&amp;CK and the detection of previously undiscovered activity. There is also a demo that walks the audience through the end-to-end process and explains TIAMATs capabilities. 
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018/measure-what-matters-how-to-use-mitre-attack-to-do-the-right-things-in-the-right-order"><span class="sr-only">Measure What Matters: How to Use MITRE ATTACK to do the Right Things in the R...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Measure What Matters: How to Use MITRE ATTACK to do the Right Things in the R..." slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Measure What Matters: How to Use MITRE ATTACK to do the Right Things in the R...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Measure What Matters: How to Use MITRE ATTACK to do the Right Things in the R... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses how to use the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework to help quantify cybersecurity risk and prioritize security projects. It outlines some of the challenges in measuring risk impact and likelihood, and how ATT&amp;CK can provide standardized threat data to help estimate risk reduction from security controls. Examples are given showing how ATT&amp;CK tactics and techniques can be mapped to existing security solutions to help compare solutions and demonstrate risk reduction through quantitative metrics. Some limitations are also discussed around needing time to calibrate estimates and the simplifications in the examples.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" Changed</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">From Theory to Practice: How My ATTACK Perspectives Have Changed</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save From Theory to Practice: How My ATTACK Perspectives Have Changed for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd4na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd4na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd4na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd4na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd4na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour December 2020

By Katie Nickels, Director of Intelligence, Red Canary

Good analysts (and good human beings) change their minds based on new information. In this presentation, Katie will share how her perspectives on ATT&amp;CK have changed since moving from ATT&amp;CK team member to ATT&amp;CK end-user. She will discuss how her ideas about coverage, procedures, and detection creation have evolved and why those perspectives matter. Katie will also share practical examples from observed threats to help explain the nuances of her perspectives. Attendees should expect to leave this presentation with a better understanding of how to handle challenges they’re likely to face when navigating their own ATT&amp;CK journey.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15na7f6:" popovertarget=":R15na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-espionage-nation-stateaptattacksontherise/53166502"><span class="sr-only">Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:4" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/cyberespionage-nationstateaptattacksontherise-150924184657-lva1-app6892-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber espionage nation state-apt_attacks_on_the_rise</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/Cyphort">Cyphort</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In the digital age, one of the most effective ways to gather data and information about a potential enemy state is by infiltrating their ranks with malware. This webinar takes a deep drive into advanced persistent threat attacks performed by nation states. We will discuss various actors, government sponsored hackers, such as Duke, Bear, and Panda. Then we will look at malware created, like Regin, Elise, Flame, Equation Group, Babar, OnionDuke, and Dark Hotel.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-5" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R16na7f6:" popovertarget=":R16na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R16na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attckcon-2018-hunters-attcking-with-the-data-robert-rodriguez-specterops-and-jose-luis-rodriguez-student/123180368"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:5" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2018mitreattckconrodriguez-181116142308-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: Hunters ATT&amp;CKing with the Data, Roberto Rodriguez, Spe... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">With the development of the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and its categorization of adversary activity during the attack cycle, understanding what to hunt for has become easier and more efficient than ever. However, organizations are still struggling to understand how they can prioritize the development of hunt hypothesis, assess their current security posture, and develop the right analytics with the help of ATT&amp;CK. Even though there are several ways to utilize ATT&amp;CK to accomplish those goals, there are only a few that are focusing primarily on the data that is currently being collected to drive the success of a hunt program. 

This presentation shows how organizations can benefit from mapping their current visibility from a data perspective to the ATT&amp;CK framework. It focuses on how to identify, document, standardize and model current available data to enhance a hunt program. It presents an updated ThreatHunter-Playbook, a Kibana ATT&amp;CK dashboard, a new project named Open Source Security Events Metadata known as OSSEM and expands on the “data sources” section already provided by ATT&amp;CK on most of the documented adversarial techniques. 
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime data-cy="slideshow-title">Mapping ATT&amp;CK Techniques to ENGAGE Activities</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By David Barroso, CounterCraft

When an adversary engages in a specific behavior, they are vulnerable to expose an unintended weakness. By looking at each ATT&amp;CK technique, we can examine the weaknesses revealed and identify an engagement activity or activities to exploit this weakness.

During the presentation we will see some real examples of how we can use different ATT&amp;CK techniques in order to plan different adversary engagement activities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18na7f6:" popovertarget=":R18na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18na7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/the-cyber-threat-intelligence-matrix/67745151"><span class="sr-only">The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-cy="slideshow-title">The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save The Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/FrodeHommedal">Frode Hommedal</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">As we get to know what life in the digital domain is like, one of the revelations we&#x27;ve had is that many large and plenty of smaller organisations are targets of espionage, of the nefarious APT.

During the last decade, it has become gospel to wait, watch, analyse and learn if you detect such an attacker in your infrastructure. Why? Because you get one chance to do the eviction of the attacker right. And if you fail, all your efforts will eventually have been for nothing.

But for how long should you wait and watch? When have you watched long enough? When have you learned enough? And how do you make that decision?

That is the challenge I hope the Cyber Threat Intelligence Matrix can help you face in a more structured manner.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9na7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9na7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9na7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9na7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Jared Stroud, Lacework

Adversaries target common cloud misconfigurations in container-focused workflows for initial access. Whether this is Docker or Kubernetes environments, Lacework Labs has identified adversaries attempting to deploy malicious container images (T1610) , mine Cryptocurrency (T1496), and deploy C2 agents. Defenders new to the container space may be unaware of the built-in capabilities popular container runtime engines have that can help defend against rogue containers being deployed into their environment. Attendees will walk away with an understanding of what these attack patterns look like based on honeypot data Lacework has gathered over the past year, as well as techniques on how to defend their own container focused workloads.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19na7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19na7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-9" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ana7f6:" popovertarget=":R1ana7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ana7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/putting-mitre-attck-into-action-with-what-you-have-where-you-are/143650354"><span class="sr-only">Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:9" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdana7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdana7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdana7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdana7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdana7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ana7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ana7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-10" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1bna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1bna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1bna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/automating-the-mundanity-of-technique-ids-with-attck-detections-collector/251521612"><span class="sr-only">Automating the mundanity of technique IDs with ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:10" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Automating the mundanity of technique IDs with ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/automatingthemundanityoftechniqueidswithattckdetectionscollector-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Automating the mundanity of technique IDs with ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/automatingthemundanityoftechniqueidswithattckdetectionscollector-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Automating the mundanity of technique IDs with ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Automating the mundanity of technique IDs with ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdbna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdbna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdbna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Marcus LaFerrera and Ryan Kovar, Splunk

Since the release of MITRE ATT&amp;CK, vendors and governmental bodies have begun mapping their security blogs, whitepapers, and threat intel reports to ATT&amp;CK TTPs, which is incredible! Vendors have then begun mapping their detections to those mapped TTPs, which is even more awesome! What is not awesome is dissecting a piece of prose for all of the specific embedded ATT&amp;CK technique IDs and then mapping them to your detections to determine coverage. Over the last year, the team at Splunk has spent more time doing this than they would like to admit, so they wrote a tool to do it for them and want to share it with the world.  Join the Splunk team as they tell the world about ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector (ADC). ADC is an open-source python tool that will allow you to extract MITRE technique IDs from a third-party URLs and output them into a file. If you use Splunk, the team even maps them to their existing (previously mapped) detection corpus. They even added the ability to export them into a navigator json for fun, profit, or (at least) better visualization!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1cna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1cna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1cna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/2021015-solarwinds-supply-chain-attack-why-we-should-take-it-sereously/241484892"><span class="sr-only">2021/0/15 - Solarwinds supply chain attack: why we should take it sereously</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:11" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="2021/0/15 - Act fast, be aware!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1dna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1dna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1dna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/attcking-the-redblue-divide/251521614"><span class="sr-only">ATT&amp;CKing the Red/Blue Divide</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="ATT&amp;CKing the Red/Blue Divide" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/attckingtheredbluedivide-220406003028-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">ATT&amp;CKing the Red/Blue Divide</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CKing the Red/Blue Divide for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbddna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbddna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbddna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Fred Frey and Jonathan Mulholland, SnapAttack

Atomic Red Team and Sigma are the largest open-source attack simulation and analytic projects. Many organizations utilize one or both internally for security controls validation or supplementing their detections and alerts.  Building on the work from these two great communities, we smashed (scientific-term) the attacks and analytics together and applied data science to analyze the results. We&#x27;ll describe our methodology and testing framework, show the real-world MITRE ATT&amp;CK coverage and gaps, discuss our algorithms for calculating analytic similarity, identifying log sources for a technique, and determining the best analytics to deploy that maximizes ATT&amp;CK coverage. 

This project aims to: 
- Bring a measurable testing rigor to community analytics to improve adoption 
- Test every analytic against every attack, validating the true positive detection 
- Understand the log sources required to detect specific attack techniques  
- Apply data science to identify analytic similarity (reduce community duplication) 
- Identify gaps between the projects&#x27; analytics without attack simulations; attack simulations without detections; missing or incorrect MITRE ATT&amp;CK labels, etc 
- Automate the process so insights can stay up to date with new attack/analytic contributions over time  
- Share our analysis back to the community to improve these projects</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div Charles 10--6-22.pptx</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CapitolTechU">CapitolTechU</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The presentation discusses open-source intelligence (OSINT) techniques. It defines OSINT as the collection and analysis of publicly available information to produce actionable intelligence. The presenter outlines the OSINT process, which includes planning, collection, processing, analysis, and dissemination. Various OSINT tools, techniques and frameworks are also discussed, such as using web browsers, text recovery tools, archiving tools, and the multi-layered and mixed-media nature of the internet. The presentation provides an overview of how to effectively perform OSINT investigations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdgna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdgna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdgna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Aunshul Rege, Katorah Williams, and Rachel Bleiman, Temple University

Social engineering (SE) is a technique used by cybercriminals to psychologically manipulate individuals into disclosing sensitive information and providing unauthorized access. Penetration testers are tasked with simulating targeted attacks on a company&#x27;s system to determine any weaknesses in their environment. 

The 2021 Summer SE Pen Test Competition allowed students to experience SE pen testing in a safe and ethical way. Student teams were &quot;hired&quot; to conduct a SE pen test on the CARE Lab (run by the authors) and their employees (the authors themselves)! Teams had to use OSINT, phishing, and vishing in real-time to target the lab, develop attack playbooks, and map the techniques to the ATT&amp;CK framework. 

This talk shares the application of ATT&amp;CK in cybersecurity education. Specifically, it (i) focuses on how students map their SE attack playbooks to the ATT&amp;CK framework, (ii) compares/contrasts SE techniques across various student groups: 6 graduate teams, 9 undergraduate teams, and 1 high school team, and (iii) how ATT&amp;CK can be used for SE.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1hna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1hna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1hna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-intelligence-47523086/47523086"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:16" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bigsecuritydata-150428120541-conversion-gate02-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Cyber Threat Intelligence" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/bigsecuritydata-150428120541-conversion-gate02-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Cyber Threat Intelligence for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/trialgtun">mohamed nasri</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses cyber threat intelligence and strategies for defense. It begins with an introduction to cyber threat intelligence and discusses the cyber attack life cycle model from Lockheed Martin. It then addresses questions to consider regarding cyber threats. The document outlines threat intelligence standards and tools like STIX and TAXII, and discusses challenges with SIEM systems. It proposes architectures that incorporate threat intelligence to provide preventive, detective, and fusion capabilities. The presentation concludes with a discussion of data sources and architectures to support cyber threat analysis.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-17" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ina7f6:" popovertarget=":R1ina7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ina7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/first-cti-symposium-turning-intelligence-into-action-with-mitre-attck/137170283"><span class="sr-only">FIRST CTI Symposium: Turning intelligence into action aria-controls=":R1jna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1jna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1jna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/analysing-ransomware/144083200"><span class="sr-only">Analysing Ransomware</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:18" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Analysing Ransomware" class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Analysing Ransomware</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Analysing Ransomware for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdjna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdjna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdjna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdjna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdjna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/WilliamBuchanan1">Napier University</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Ransomware has evolved significantly since 2012, starting as police messages and becoming increasingly sophisticated with encryption and evasion techniques. Ransomware distributors now offer ransomware-as-a-service and use affiliate programs to spread malware via phishing emails and drive-by downloads. Victims&#x27; files are encrypted with strong encryption keys while private keys remain with criminal operators, who demand ransom payments in cryptocurrency. Effective defenses include education, backups, layered protection, network segmentation, and application control to limit the impact of ransomware attacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1jna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-19" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1kna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1kna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1kna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attck-framework/236612661"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:19" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdkna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdkna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdkna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdkna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdkna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/null0x00">n|u - The Open Security Community</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is a knowledge base of adversary behaviors and tactics collected from real-world observations. It describes how the framework categorizes behaviors using tactics, techniques, and procedures. The framework can be used for threat intelligence, detection and analytics, adversary emulation, and assessment and engineering. The document provides examples of how organizations can map their detection capabilities and data sources to techniques in the framework to improve visibility of attacks. It cautions against misusing the framework as a checklist rather than taking a threat-informed approach.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1kna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1kna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:20" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdlna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdlna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/BhushanGurav2">Bhushan Gurav</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework is about the framework that is followed by Threat Hunters, Threat Analysts for Threat Modelling purpose, which can be use for Adversary Emulation and Attack Defense. Cybersecurity Analyst widely use it for framing the attack through its various used Tactics and Techniques.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1lna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1lna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-21" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1mna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1mna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1mna7f6"><a class="sr-only">Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM]</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:21" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM]" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM]</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM] for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdmna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdmna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdmna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdmna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdmna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/dgsweigert">David Sweigert</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">William F. Crowe presented on the cybersecurity kill chain, which models the stages of a cyber attack based on military doctrine. The model developed by Lockheed Martin includes stages of reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, command and control, and actions on objectives. ISACA and the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security also use similar kill chain models to analyze the process of advanced persistent threats targeting critical systems and data.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1mna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1mna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-22" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1nna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1nna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1nna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-attck-coverage-anyway-breadth-and-depth-analysis-with-atomic-red-team/251521611"><span class="sr-only">What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:22" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisattckcoverageanyway-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisattckcoverageanyway-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdnna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdnna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdnna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdnna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdnna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Brian Donohue, Red Canary

This presentation will highlight the Atomic Red Team project&#x27;s efforts to define and increase the test coverage of MITRE ATT&amp;CK techniques. We&#x27;ll describe the challenges we encountered in defining what &quot;coverage&quot; means in the context of an ATT&amp;CK-based framework, and how to use that definition to improve an open source project that&#x27;s used by a diverse audience of practitioners to satisfy an equally diverse array of needs. The audience will learn how the Atomic Red Team maintainers standardize and categorize atomic tests, perform gap analysis to achieve deep technique-level coverage and broad matrix-level coverage, and quickly fill those gaps with new tests.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1nna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1nna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ona7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/transforming-adversary-emulation-into-a-data-analysis-question/241296467"><span class="sr-only">Transforming Adversary Emulation Into a Data Analysis Question</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:23" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a a Data Analysis Question for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdona7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdona7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdona7f6"><span class="icon style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdona7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdona7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour October 2020

By Matan Hart, Co-Founder &amp; CEO Cymptom @machosec 

Adversary emulation is commonly used to validate security controls and is considered one of the most popular use-cases for the ATT&amp;CK framework. However, emulating adversary TTPs on production environments is often very limited in testing scope and frequency, and such practice may cause unwanted business disruption. In this talk from the MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour session on October 9, 2020, Hart presents a different approach to testing controls against ATT&amp;CK. He demonstrates how it is possible to provide data-based methods to evaluate the exploitability of ATT&amp;CK techniques by gathering information from the network, endpoint, and services; this unique approach does not emulate any sort of malicious action, thus reducing the potential of causing business disruption to the minimum. Hart also outlines a new open-source guideline based on ATT&amp;CK mitigations, that security teams can use to assess their security posture non-intrusively and at scale.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ona7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ona7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="recommended-card-description-24" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1pna7f6:" popovertarget=":R1pna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1pna7f6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attckcon-2018-from-automation-to-analytics-simulating-the-adversary-to-create-better-detections-david-herrald-and-ryan-kovar-splunk/123180390"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:24" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ..." src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2018mitreattckconherraldkovar-181116142318-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdpna7f6:" popovertarget=":Rbdpna7f6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdpna7f6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdpna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdpna7f6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Security teams have more detection tools at their disposal than ever before, yet most are still struggling to find even the most basic malicious activity occurring in their environments. Building effective detection analytics requires realistic data and the ability to iterate quickly in a rapid analytic development cycle. 
This talk introduces a full lifecycle attack simulation and analytics development environment featuring the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and the Atomic Red Team project using Splunk and Splunk Phantom mapped to an imaginary APT group, Taedonggang.  

It focuses on how security teams can use such a system to rapidly develop and share new detection analytics. Links to all components referenced in the talk are provided, including a cloud-based dataset that can act as a playground for users who want to see the results of the activity. 
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1pna7f6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1pna7f6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using storytelling to increase understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1qna7f6:" popover="manual" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cyber threat intelligence and collaborative threat intelligence. It provides an overview of malware trends, requirements for developing threat intelligence capabilities, and principles for managing threat intelligence proactively. The document advocates for a collaborative threat intelligence framework to enable preventative response by identifying and blocking known attackers across multiple organizations through automated and real-time threat information sharing. Standards and tools discussed include IODEF, CIF and how CIF can be used to gather, identify, respond to and mitigate threats based on indicators collected from various sources.</span></div></div><div threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div Cloud</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CKING Containers in The Cloud for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd1c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd1c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Jared Stroud, Lacework

Adversaries target common cloud misconfigurations in container-focused workflows for initial access. Whether this is Docker or Kubernetes environments, Lacework Labs has identified adversaries attempting to deploy malicious container images (T1610) , mine Cryptocurrency (T1496), and deploy C2 agents. Defenders new to the container space may be unaware of the built-in capabilities popular container runtime engines have that can help defend against rogue containers being deployed into their environment. Attendees will walk away with an understanding of what these attack patterns look like based on honeypot data Lacework has gathered over the past year, as well as techniques on how to defend their own container focused workloads.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R11c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-1" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R12c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R12c9jnf6:" Where You Are</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:1" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img Action with What You Have, Where You Are</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into Action with What You Have, Where You Are for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd2c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd2c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd2c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd2c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd2c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/KatieNickels">Katie Nickels</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document provides an overview of Katie Nickels&#x27; presentation on putting MITRE ATT&amp;CK into action using available resources. Some key points include:
- MITRE ATT&amp;CK is a knowledge base of adversary tactics and techniques based on real-world observations. 
- It can be used for detection, assessment, threat intelligence, and adversary emulation.
- For detection, ATT&amp;CK can help improve focus on post-exploit activity and track gaps/improvements in coverage over time. Existing data sources can be leveraged to detect techniques.
- For assessment and engineering, ATT&amp;CK can guide decisions around tool selection and help identify visibility and risk acceptance gaps.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R12c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R12c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-2" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R13c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R13c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R13c9jnf6"><a ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:2" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2"
