Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Automating the mundanity of technique IDs with ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Marcus LaFerrera and Ryan Kovar, Splunk

Since the release of MITRE ATT&amp;CK, vendors and governmental bodies have begun mapping their security blogs, whitepapers, and threat intel reports to ATT&amp;CK TTPs, which is incredible! Vendors have then begun mapping their detections to those mapped TTPs, which is even more awesome! What is not awesome is dissecting a piece of prose for all of the specific embedded ATT&amp;CK technique IDs and then mapping them to your detections to determine coverage. Over the last year, the team at Splunk has spent more time doing this than they would like to admit, so they wrote a tool to do it for them and want to share it with the world.  Join the Splunk team as they tell the world about ATT&amp;CK Detections Collector (ADC). ADC is an open-source python tool that will allow you to extract MITRE technique IDs from a third-party URLs and output them into a file. If you use Splunk, the team even maps them to their existing (previously mapped) detection corpus. They even added the ability to export them into a navigator json for fun, profit, or (at least) better visualization!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-3" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R14c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R14c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R14c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/2021015-solarwinds-supply-chain-attack-why-we-should-take-it-sereously/241484892"><span class="sr-only">2021/0/15 - Solarwinds supply chain attack: why we should take it sereously</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:3" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="2021/0/15 - Solarwinds supply chain attack: why we should take it sereously</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save 2021/0/15 - Act fast, be aware!</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save ATT&amp;CKing the Red/Blue Divide for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd5c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd5c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Fred Frey and Jonathan Mulholland, SnapAttack

Atomic Red Team and Sigma are the largest open-source attack simulation and analytic projects. Many organizations utilize one or both internally for security controls validation or supplementing their detections and alerts.  Building on the work from these two great communities, we smashed (scientific-term) the attacks and analytics together and applied data science to analyze the results. We&#x27;ll describe our methodology and testing framework, show the real-world MITRE ATT&amp;CK coverage and gaps, discuss our algorithms for calculating analytic similarity, identifying log sources for a technique, and determining the best analytics to deploy that maximizes ATT&amp;CK coverage. 

This project aims to: 
- Bring a measurable testing rigor to community analytics to improve adoption 
- Test every analytic against every attack, validating the true positive detection 
- Understand the log sources required to detect specific attack techniques  
- Apply data science to identify analytic similarity (reduce community duplication) 
- Identify gaps between the projects&#x27; analytics without attack simulations; attack simulations without detections; missing or incorrect MITRE ATT&amp;CK labels, etc 
- Automate the process so insights can stay up to date with new attack/analytic contributions over time  
- Share our analysis back to the community to improve these projects</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Mitre ATT&amp;CK is for all of us, and it is time to pay attention to it.
LOG-MD.com
LOG-MD
MalwareArchaeology.com
Malware Archaeology</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R16c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-6" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R17c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R17c9jnf6:" class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:6" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Charles 10--6-22.pptx</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CapitolTechU">CapitolTechU</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The presentation discusses open-source intelligence (OSINT) techniques. It defines OSINT as the collection and analysis of publicly available information to produce actionable intelligence. The presenter outlines the OSINT process, which includes planning, collection, processing, analysis, and dissemination. Various OSINT tools, techniques and frameworks are also discussed, such as using web browsers, text recovery tools, archiving tools, and the multi-layered and mixed-media nature of the internet. The presentation provides an overview of how to effectively perform OSINT investigations.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R17c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R17c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-7" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R18c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R18c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R18c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" class="sr-only">Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:7" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Exploring how Students Map Social Engineering Techniques to the ATT&amp;CK Framew... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd8c9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd8c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd8c9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Aunshul Rege, Katorah Williams, and Rachel Bleiman, Temple University

Social engineering (SE) is a technique used by cybercriminals to psychologically manipulate individuals into disclosing sensitive information and providing unauthorized access. Penetration testers are tasked with simulating targeted attacks on a company&#x27;s system to determine any weaknesses in their environment. 

The 2021 Summer SE Pen Test Competition allowed students to experience SE pen testing in a safe and ethical way. Student teams were &quot;hired&quot; to conduct a SE pen test on the CARE Lab (run by the authors) and their employees (the authors themselves)! Teams had to use OSINT, phishing, and vishing in real-time to target the lab, develop attack playbooks, and map the techniques to the ATT&amp;CK framework. 

This talk shares the application of ATT&amp;CK in cybersecurity education. Specifically, it (i) focuses on how students map their SE attack playbooks to the ATT&amp;CK framework, (ii) compares/contrasts SE techniques across various student groups: 6 graduate teams, 9 undergraduate teams, and 1 high school team, and (iii) how ATT&amp;CK can be used for SE.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R18c9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R18c9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-8" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R19c9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R19c9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R19c9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/cyber-threat-intelligence-47523086/47523086"><span class="sr-only">Cyber Threat Intelligence</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses cyber threat intelligence and strategies for defense. It begins with an introduction to cyber threat intelligence and discusses the cyber attack life cycle model from Lockheed Martin. It then addresses questions to consider regarding cyber threats. The document outlines threat intelligence standards and tools like STIX and TAXII, and discusses challenges with SIEM systems. It proposes architectures that incorporate threat intelligence to provide preventive, detective, and fusion capabilities. The presentation concludes with a discussion of data sources and architectures to support cyber threat analysis.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19c9jnf6:" popover="manual" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/analysing-ransomware/144083200"><span class="sr-only">Analysing Ransomware</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Analysing Ransomware</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Analysing Ransomware for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdbc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdbc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdbc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdbc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdbc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/WilliamBuchanan1">Napier University</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Ransomware has evolved significantly since 2012, starting as police messages and becoming increasingly sophisticated with encryption and evasion techniques. Ransomware distributors now offer ransomware-as-a-service and use affiliate programs to spread malware via phishing emails and drive-by downloads. Victims&#x27; files are encrypted with strong encryption keys while private keys remain with criminal operators, who demand ransom payments in cryptocurrency. Effective defenses include education, backups, layered protection, network segmentation, and application control to limit the impact of ransomware attacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1cc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1cc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1cc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attck-framework/236612661"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:11" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontomitreattck-200328091951-200705113109-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/introductiontomitreattck-200328091951-200705113109-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CK Framework for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdcc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdcc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdcc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdcc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdcc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/null0x00">n|u - The Open Security Community</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework, which is a knowledge base of adversary behaviors and tactics collected from real-world observations. It describes how the framework categorizes behaviors using tactics, techniques, and procedures. The framework can be used for threat intelligence, detection and analytics, adversary emulation, and assessment and engineering. The document provides examples of how organizations can map their detection capabilities and data sources to techniques in the framework to improve visibility of attacks. It cautions against misusing the framework as a checklist rather than taking a threat-informed approach.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1cc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1cc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-12" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1dc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1dc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1dc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/mitre-attck-framework-250898466/250898466"><span class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:12" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/mitreattckframework-211225144123-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbddc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbddc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ for Threat Modelling purpose, which can be use for Adversary Emulation and Attack Defense. Cybersecurity Analyst widely use it for framing the attack through its various used Tactics and Techniques.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1dc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-13" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ec9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ec9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/overview-of-the-cyber-kill-chain-tm/69998265"><span class="sr-only">Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM]</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:13" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM]" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM]</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Overview of the Cyber Kill Chain [TM] for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdec9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdec9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdec9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/dgsweigert">David Sweigert</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">William F. Crowe presented on the cybersecurity kill chain, which models the stages of a cyber attack based on military doctrine. The model developed by Lockheed Martin includes stages of reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, command and control, and actions on objectives. ISACA and the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security also use similar kill chain models to analyze the process of advanced persistent threats targeting critical systems and data.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ec9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ec9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-14" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1fc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1fc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1fc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/what-is-attck-coverage-anyway-breadth-and-depth-analysis-with-atomic-red-team/251521611"><span class="sr-only">What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:14" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisattckcoverageanyway-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/whatisattckcoverageanyway-220406003027-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save What is ATT&amp;CK coverage, anyway? Breadth and depth analysis with Atomic Red Team for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdfc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdfc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdfc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdfc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdfc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From ATT&amp;CKcon 3.0

By Brian Donohue, Red Canary

This presentation will highlight the Atomic Red Team project&#x27;s efforts to define and increase the test coverage of MITRE ATT&amp;CK techniques. We&#x27;ll describe the challenges we encountered in defining what &quot;coverage&quot; means in the context of an ATT&amp;CK-based framework, and how to use that definition to improve an open source project that&#x27;s used by a diverse audience of practitioners to satisfy an equally diverse array of needs. The audience will learn how the Atomic Red Team maintainers standardize and categorize atomic tests, perform gap analysis to achieve deep technique-level coverage and broad matrix-level coverage, and quickly fill those gaps with new tests.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1fc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-15" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1gc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1gc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1gc9jnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/transforming-adversary-emulation-into-a-data-analysis-question/241296467"><span class="sr-only">Transforming Adversary Emulation Into a Data Analysis Question</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:15" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A Thumbnail_cover__1zsIi" alt="Transforming Adversary Emulation Into a Data Analysis Question" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Transforming Adversary Emulation Into a Data Analysis Question</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Transforming Adversary Emulation Into a Data Analysis Question for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdgc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdgc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdgc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">From MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour October 2020

By Matan Hart, Co-Founder &amp; CEO Cymptom @machosec 

Adversary emulation is commonly used to validate security controls and is considered one of the most popular use-cases for the ATT&amp;CK framework. However, emulating adversary TTPs on production environments is often very limited in testing scope and frequency, and such practice may cause unwanted business disruption. In this talk from the MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon Power Hour session on October 9, 2020, Hart presents a different approach to testing controls against ATT&amp;CK. He demonstrates how it is possible to provide data-based methods to evaluate the exploitability of ATT&amp;CK techniques by gathering information from the network, endpoint, and services; this unique approach does not emulate any sort of malicious action, thus reducing the potential of causing business disruption to the minimum. Hart also outlines a new open-source guideline based on ATT&amp;CK mitigations, that security teams can use to assess their security posture non-intrusively and at scale.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="whatsHot-card-description-16" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1hc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":R1hc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1hc9jnf6"><a class="sr-only">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ...</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/2018mitreattckconherraldkovar-181116142318-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/></div><div class="SlideshowCard_content__xh7kV slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ...</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save MITRE ATT&amp;CKcon 2018: From Automation to Analytics: Simulating the Adversary ... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdhc9jnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdhc9jnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdhc9jnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdhc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdhc9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/attackcon2018">MITRE - ATT&amp;CKcon</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Security teams have more detection tools at their disposal than ever before, yet most are still struggling to find even the most basic malicious activity occurring in their environments. Building effective detection analytics requires realistic data and the ability to iterate quickly in a rapid analytic development cycle. 
This talk introduces a full lifecycle attack simulation and analytics development environment featuring the MITRE ATT&amp;CK framework and the Atomic Red Team project using Splunk and Splunk Phantom mapped to an imaginary APT group, Taedonggang.  

It focuses on how security teams can use such a system to rapidly develop and share new detection analytics. Links to all components referenced in the talk are provided, including a cloud-based dataset that can act as a playground for users who want to see the results of the activity. 
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1hc9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1hc9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime data-cy="slideshow-title">Knowledge for the masses: Storytelling with ATT&amp;CK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdic9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdic9jnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/MITREATTACK">MITRE ATT&amp;CK</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses using storytelling to increase understanding of cyber threats through ATT&amp;CK threat sightings. It describes the AC3 methodology for documenting threat actor tactics, techniques, and procedures with full context and observables. Different levels of abstraction and tools are used to translate threat sightings into various formats to ensure understanding across audiences. Maintaining defensive playbooks adapted from threat sightings helps continuous understanding and improvement of defenses.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ic9jnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ic9jnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" events to monitor, detect and prevent threats to an organisation, shifting the focus from reactive to preventive intelligent security measures.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1jc9jnf6:" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/prachimishra31">Prachi Mishra</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses cyber threat intelligence and collaborative threat intelligence. It provides an overview of malware trends, requirements for developing threat intelligence capabilities, and principles for managing threat intelligence proactively. The document advocates for a collaborative threat intelligence framework to enable preventative response by identifying and blocking known attackers across multiple organizations through automated and real-time threat information sharing. Standards and tools discussed include IODEF, CIF and how CIF can be used to gather, identify, respond to and mitigate threats based on indicators collected from various sources.</span></div></div><div class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">In today’s threat environment, adversaries are constantly profiling and attacking your corporate infrastructure to access and collect your intellectual property, proprietary data, and trade secrets. Now, more than ever, Threat Intelligence is increasingly important for organizations who want to proactively defend against advanced threat actors.

While many organizations today are collecting massive amount of threat intelligence, are they able to translate the information into an effective defense strategy?

View the slides now to learn about threat intelligence for operational purposes, including real-world demonstrations of how to consume intelligence and integrate it with existing security infrastructure.

Learn how to prioritize response by differentiating between commodity and targeted attacks and develop a defense that responds to specific methods used by advanced attackers.</span></div></div><div Attack</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save CrowdCasts Monthly: When Pandas Attack for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd3cajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd3cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd3cajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd3cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd3cajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes a CrowdStrike webinar on detecting advanced malware-free intrusions. It describes three speakers from CrowdStrike - Dmitri Alperovitch, Chris Scott, and Adam Meyers. The webinar then discusses how adversaries like China and various state-sponsored and criminal groups are adapting their tactics to evade detection, and how security teams must also adapt detection methods to focus on real-time monitoring rather than indicators of compromise. The webinar includes a case study of detecting a webshell attack in near real-time using CrowdStrike Falcon Host and concludes with a demonstration of its endpoint protection capabilities.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R13cajnf6"></div><div class="separator It notes that the mining industry, like other industries, is increasingly relying on integrated and automated systems, leaving it vulnerable to cyber attacks. The mining industry deals with targeted cyber espionage campaigns and disruptive attacks aimed at exploiting its strategic role in global supply chains. The document provides an overview of modern mining operations and infrastructure, noting their complexity and geographical distribution, before examining specific cybersecurity issues and threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R14cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="similarTo-card-description-4" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R15cajnf6:" popovertarget=":R15cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R15cajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/FrankBackes/cybersecurity-a-community-approach-20151109"><span class="sr-only">Cybersecurity A Community Approach - slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">Bear Hunting: History and Attribution of Russian Intelligence Operations</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Bear Hunting: History and Attribution of Russian Intelligence Operations for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd9cajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd9cajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd9cajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd9cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd9cajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Learn about the history of Russian intelligence influence operations and the cyber actors implementing them today.

In June 2016, CrowdStrike exposed unprecedented efforts by Russian intelligence services to interfere in the U.S. election via the hacking and subsequent leaking of information from political organizations and individuals. Election manipulation was not a new activity for the Russians - they have engaged in these influence operations consistently for the better part of the last two decades inside and outside of Russia.

In this CrowdCast, CrowdStrike experts Adam Meyers, VP of Intelligence, and Dmitri Alperovitch, Co-Founder &amp; CTO, will provide a detailed overview of the history of Russian intelligence influence operations going back decades and provide a deep dive overview of various BEAR (including FANCY BEAR AND COZY BEAR) intrusion sets and their tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). They will also discuss the considerable attribution evidence that CrowdStrike has collected from a variety of investigations into their operations and lay out the case for the Russian government connection to these hacks.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R19cajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R19cajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY style="anchor-name:--popover-R1acajnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" data-cy="slideshow-title">SOCRadar 2024 Canada Threat Landscape Report</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save SOCRadar 2024 Canada Threat Landscape Report for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdacajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdacajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdacajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdacajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdacajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/socradar">SOCRadar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Canada’s cybersecurity risks are escalating, with finance and insurance industries making up 12.66% of dark web targets. Ransomware attacks continue to threaten the manufacturing sector, representing 21.11% of cases. LockBit leads the ransomware groups, responsible for 30.3% of attacks. Additionally, stealer logs expose over 208,000 email-password combinations, putting critical systems and sensitive data at risk.

Phishing threats have surged, with cryptocurrency-related attacks comprising 31.66% of incidents. Meanwhile, Canada faced over 110,000 DDoS attacks, signaling the urgent need for organizations to bolster defenses. Threat actors are increasingly leveraging stolen credentials and targeting vulnerable industries.

SOCRadar’s proactive threat intelligence solutions empower Canadian organizations to stay ahead of evolving cyber threats. Detect dark web activities, mitigate ransomware risks, and safeguard your assets with real-time monitoring. Download the full CISO brief now to secure your organization’s future.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1acajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/lkcyber">lkcyber</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">RSA Quick Look Webcast: http://www.rsaconference.com/media/quick-look-proactive-counterespionage-as-a-part-of-business-continuity-and-resiliency

This white paper corresponds to the RSA Presentation entitled: &quot;Proactive Counterespionage as a Part of Business Continuity and Resiliency&quot;
Presentation Abstract: The session will discuss means in which information assets and business continuity is protected and propose an additional layer of defense with a human counterespionage focus. The proposed proactive counterespionage plan includes operational security audits, reverse open source intelligence and classification of employees who are prime targets for disruptive espionage. - See more at: http://www.rsaconference.com/events/ad15/agenda/sessions/2219/proactive-counterespionage-as-a-part-of-business#sthash.DTYlHe6a.dpuf</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bcajnf6:" slideshow-card-content"><span class="slideshow-title SlideshowTitle_root__2VccW RailCard_title__Tvfiv ellipsis" style="-webkit-line-clamp:2" data-cy="slideshow-title">COMMON GOOD DIGITAL FRAMEWORK</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save COMMON GOOD DIGITAL FRAMEWORK for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdccajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdccajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdccajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdccajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdccajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/bostonglobalforum">Boston Global Forum</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The Common Good Digital Framework (CGDF) is a proposed campaign and platform to monitor violations of ethical values and standards related to artificial intelligence, personal data, cyber security, and digital activity by governments and large organizations. The CGDF will focus on issues like AI bias, privacy, and cyber security, and will generate policy recommendations in response to identified problems. It will utilize partners, advisors, and social media to distribute its findings and recommendations in order to influence policymaking and encourage corrective actions. The goal is to establish new ethical norms and regulations to help guide digital progress for the benefit of all humanity.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ccajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ccajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document discusses the evolution of misinformation and proposes a framework called AMITT (Attribution, Mitigation, Incident and Technique Taxonomy) to analyze misinformation campaigns and incidents. It suggests populating the AMITT framework by cataloging historical misinformation examples. Finally, it notes that further work is needed to develop mitigations and counters, refine techniques, and share intelligence using the framework.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1dcajnf6:" science. The intent of this document is to set in motion the discussion for the creation of a startup in South Africa that is focused on data science.  </span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ecajnf6:" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdfcajnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdfcajnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdfcajnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/socradar">SOCRadar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The 2024 Australia Threat Landscape Report by SOCRadar dives into the evolving cyber threats impacting Australia&#x27;s key industries, focusing on ransomware, phishing, and Dark Web activities. Key findings include:

Ransomware Surge: A substantial increase in ransomware incidents, especially from groups like Medusa, LockBit 3.0, and Akira, targeting sectors such as retail and healthcare.
Dark Web Exposure: Australian organizations are heavily featured in Dark Web data sales, with notable activity against the retail and finance sectors.
Phishing and DDoS Attacks: The rise in phishing attacks and record-breaking DDoS incidents underscores the sophistication of current cyber threats.
The report offers strategic recommendations for organizations to enhance cybersecurity resilience, leveraging SOCRadar’s Extended Threat Intelligence, which includes tools for proactive threat detection, Dark Web monitoring, and brand protection.

Get insights from the full report to safeguard your assets and strengthen cyber defenses in Australia’s challenging digital landscape.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1fcajnf6:" popover="manual" class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdgcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdgcajnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/socradar">SOCRadar</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The 2024 Australia Threat Landscape Report by SOCRadar dives into the evolving cyber threats impacting Australia&#x27;s key industries, focusing on ransomware, phishing, and Dark Web activities. Key findings include:

Ransomware Surge: A substantial increase in ransomware incidents, especially from groups like Medusa, LockBit 3.0, and Akira, targeting sectors such as retail and healthcare.
Dark Web Exposure: Australian organizations are heavily featured in Dark Web data sales, with notable activity against the retail and finance sectors.
Phishing and DDoS Attacks: The rise in phishing attacks and record-breaking DDoS incidents underscores the sophistication of current cyber threats.
The report offers strategic recommendations for organizations to enhance cybersecurity resilience, leveraging SOCRadar’s Extended Threat Intelligence, which includes tools for proactive threat detection, Dark Web monitoring, and brand protection.

Get insights from the full report to safeguard your assets and strengthen cyber defenses in Australia’s challenging digital landscape.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1gcajnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1gcajnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/cgarcia045">Cristian Garcia G.</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">This document summarizes John Kindervag&#x27;s report &quot;No More Chewy Centers: The Zero Trust Model Of Information Security&quot;. The report argues that traditional perimeter-based network security models are ineffective against modern threats like targeted attacks and malicious insiders. It introduces the &quot;Zero Trust&quot; model, which considers all network traffic untrusted and requires strict access controls and monitoring. The report recommends security professionals adopt this new model to better protect their organizations from sophisticated adversaries inside and outside the network.</span></div></div><div class="" privacy. It summarizes recent regulations on facial recognition in the US, UK, and EU. It also discusses misinformation campaigns related to protests in Hong Kong and how Twitter and Facebook have taken actions to suspend accounts spreading misinformation. The document explores how misinformation can be spread through deepfake videos and AI-generated fake news. It discusses efforts to combat fake news through fact checking and provides examples from Hong Kong and Taiwan. Finally, it calls for the IT industry to adopt an approach that puts people first, develops privacy-enabled technologies, and promotes openness and public awareness.</span></div></div><div class="" SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Where is endpoint security headed? How do your priorities and capabilities compare to those of your peers?

As the battle against breaches rages on, many enterprises are focused on revamping their endpoint security strategy – from enhancing efficacy to reducing complexity and agent bloat. A new webcast, “State of the Endpoint: The Buyer Mindset,” discusses the current state of endpoint security and offers insights from an all-star panel of thought leaders, including Internationally recognized cybersecurity leader and CrowdStrike Co-founder Dmitri Alperovitch, VP of Product Marketing Dan Larson, and other experts as they discuss today’s most important security issues. Join them as they explore the findings from a new research report, “Trends in Endpoint Security: A State of Constant Change,” a study conducted by ESG and commissioned by CrowdStrike and other technology vendors. The panel will provide their impressions of the data in the survey and how the viewpoints revealed mesh with current technology trends, offering insights that can help inform your security strategy going forward.

Join this webcast to learn:

-The current state of Antivirus (AV) including how many organizations are choosing to change vendors and why
-Best of breed vs. comprehensive suites – which approach do your peers prefer and what are the advantages and challenges of each?
-How solutions are affecting endpoints and your IT Security peers, including the increase in agents installed and the impact of increased complexity</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R11cbjnf6:" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">How adversaries use fileless attacks to evade your security and what you can do about it

Standard security solutions have continued to improve in their ability to detect and block malware and cyberattacks. This has forced cybercriminals to employ stealthier methods of evading legacy security to achieve success, including launching fileless attacks, where no executable file is written to disk. Download this presentation provided by CrowdStrike security experts to learn why so many of today’s adversaries are abandoning yesterday’s malware and relying on an evolving array of fileless exploits. 

You’ll learn how fileless attacks are conceived and executed and why they are successfully evading the standard security measures employed by most organizations. You’ll also receive guidance on the best practices for defending your organization against these stealthy, damaging attacks.

The following presentation includes:
--How a fileless attack is executed — see how an end-to-end attack unfolds
--Why fileless attacks are having so much success evading legacy security solutions
--How you can protect your organization from being victimized by a fileless attack, including the security technologies and policies that are most effective</span></div></div><div class="" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Real world lessons from CrowdStrike Services experts investigating complex cyber extortion attacks

The criminal act of theft is as old as civilization itself, but in the cyber realm new ways to steal your organization&#x27;s data or profit by holding it hostage, continue to evolve. With each advancement in security technology, adversaries work tirelessly on new techniques to bypass your defenses. This webcast, &quot;Cyber Extortion: Digital Shakedowns and How to Stop Them&quot; examines the evolution of cyber extortion techniques, including the latest &quot;datanapping&quot; exploits. Whether it&#x27;s an attack on a major movie studio, a massive healthcare system, or a global entertainment platform, recent extortion attempts demonstrate how critical it is to understand today&#x27;s threat landscape so you can ensure that your organization mounts the best defense possible.

Download this presentation to learn what security experts from the cyber defense frontlines are discussing. Learn about:

•The range of extortion techniques being used today, including commonalities and differences in approaches
•Commodity type ransomware/datanapping vs. hands-on attacks — how are they alike and what are their differences?
•Potential outcomes of paying vs. not paying when attempting to recover data after an attack
•Real world examples of successful attacks and those that were thwarted or mitigated
•Strategies for keeping your organization from being targeted and what to do if you become the victim of a cyber shakedown</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R13cbjnf6:" popover="manual" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Gain in-depth information on the massive WannaCry ransomware attack

On Friday, May 12, the WannaCry ransomware variant swept the globe. In a short period of time, WannaCry (also known as Wanna Decryptor and WannaCryptor) infected over 230,000 systems in 150 countries. It was a particularly effective piece of malware because it not only encrypted data and held it for ransom, but it also spread like wildfire to other systems. Entire organizations found themselves looking at a ransom note on their screens and wondering what to do next.

As the situation continues to unfold, please join us as Adam Myers, VP of Threat Intelligence at CrowdStrike, presents an in-depth look at the WannaCry ransomware.

Register for this webcast to learn:
-A complete technical understanding of the WannaCry threat
-What analysts were seeing on the day of the WannaCry outbreak
-How to prevent WannaCry infections and protect against ransomware going forward</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R14cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Falcon OverWatch Experts Hunt 24/7 To Stop Incidents Before They Become Breaches

Is your IT security team suffering from alert fatigue? For many organizations, chasing down every security alert can tax an already overburdened IT department, often resulting in a breach that might have been avoided. Adding to this challenge is an increase in sophisticated threats that strike so fast and frequently, traditional methods of investigation and response can’t offer adequate protection. 

A new webcast from CrowdStrike, “Proactive Threat Hunting: Game-Changing Endpoint Protection Above and Beyond Alerting,” discusses why so many organizations are vulnerable to unseen threats and alert fatigue, and why having an approach that is both reactive and proactive is key. You’ll also learn about Falcon OverWatch™, CrowdStrike’s proactive threat hunting service that investigates and responds to threats immediately, dramatically increasing your ability to react before a damaging breach occurs.

Download the webcast slides to learn:

--How constantly reacting to alerts prevents you from getting ahead of the potentially damaging threats designed to bypass standard endpoint security
--Why an approach that includes  proactive threat hunting, sometimes called Managed Detection and Response, is key to increasing protection against new and advanced threats   
--How CrowdStrike Falcon OverWatch can provide 24/7 managed threat hunting, augmenting your security efforts with a team of cyber intrusion detection analysts and investigators who proactively identify and prioritize incidents before they become damaging breaches
</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R15cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R15cbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime TARGETING THE MAC PLATFORM</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save DEFENDING AGAINST THREATS TARGETING THE MAC PLATFORM for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd6cbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd6cbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd6cbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd6cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd6cbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">CrowdStrike Falcon with next-gen AV protects your Mac-based organization

If your organization has moved to a Mac-based platform, or are considering it, you may be aware that threats targeting Mac devices are on the rise. A new webcast from CrowdStrike, &quot;Defending Against Threats Targeting the Mac Platform&quot; discusses how the increase in Mac adoptions has given rise to a new class of targeted threats and explains why standard security solutions can&#x27;t protect you.

In this CrowdCast, Peter Ingebrigtsen, as discussed why more companies are switching to the Mac platform, the new threats targeting Macs, and what you can do to better protect your organization.

Download the slides to learn:
Why more IT departments are switching to the Mac platform
How new threats targeting Macs are able to bypass standard security measures
How CrowdStrike&#x27;s next-gen AV employs machine learning and behavioral analytics to defend against threats aimed at the Mac platform

On-Demand CrowdCast Link: https://www.crowdstrike.com/resources/crowdcasts/defending-threats-targeting-mac-platform/</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R16cbjnf6:" popover="manual" save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save CrowdStrike CrowdCast: Is Ransomware Morphing Beyond The Ability Of Standard ... for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbd7cbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbd7cbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbd7cbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbd7cbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbd7cbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Learn how to prevent &amp; detect even the most complex “file-less” ransomware exploits

Ransomware continues to evolve as perpetrators develop new exploits with consequences that can be dramatic and immediate. The purveyors of ransomware continue to prosper with adversaries developing new strains such as Zepto and Cerber that are proving to be more challenging than ever. Other exploits can alter programmable logic controller (PLC) parameters and adversely impact mechanical systems. Clearly, new defense approaches are needed because organizations can no longer rely on backups and conventional security solutions to protect them. Join CrowdStrike Senior Security Architect Dan Brown as he offers details on these sophisticated new ransomware threats, and reveals recent innovations designed to offer better protection – including new indicator of attack (IOA) behavioral analysis methodologies that can detect and prevent even the most complex “file-less” ransomware exploits.

Attend this CrowdCast where Dan will discuss:
--The challenges of defending against dangerous new variants, such as Zepto and Cerber
--Real-world examples of ransomware in action and the sophisticated tactics being used by a variety of adversaries
--How the CrowdStrike Falcon cloud-delivered platform can defend your organization against new super strains of ransomware that use sophisticated malware-free tactics

provides more effective protection than legacy antivirus solutions. endpoint security providers have embraced the cloud as the ideal way to deliver their solutions. Yet, incorporating cloud services into legacy architectures limits their ability to fully engage the tremendous power the cloud offers.

CrowdStrike Falcon recognized the value of cloud-delivery from the beginning, developing architecture built from the ground up to take full advantage of the cloud. CrowdStrike’s cloud-powered endpoint security not only ensures rapid deployment and infinite scalability, it increases your security posture by enabling real-time advanced threat protection across even the largest, distributed enterprises.

•The advantages of endpoint protection purpose-built for the cloud – why it allows you to take full advantage of the cloud’s power

RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses the need for a balanced approach to endpoint security that includes both prevention and detection. It argues that relying solely on prevention is not sufficient, as attacks will always get through, requiring detection capabilities to identify breaches. Likewise, detection alone is insufficient, as preventing attacks upfront reduces workload. The document outlines the key components needed to properly unify next-generation antivirus and endpoint detection and response, including complete visibility of endpoint activity, large-scale analysis capacity, and the ability to derive insights and indicators of attack from collected data. An integrated approach is advocated that allows prevention and detection to strengthen one another.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1acbjnf6:" popover="manual" Machine Learning </span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">The document discusses how machine learning can be used to battle unknown malware. It provides examples of using machine learning techniques like feature selection, dimensionality reduction, and classification on military personnel data and malware samples. While machine learning is effective against most malware, it is not enough on its own as many attacks do not use malware. A comprehensive prevention approach is needed to address the full spectrum of threats.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1bcbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1bcbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" style="--color:var(--blue-gray-200);--size:1px" role="separator"></div><div class="RailCard_root__rZUGY RailCard_hasDescription__MjSgf SlideshowCard_root__pD8t4 slideshow-card" aria-describedby="moreFromUser-card-description-11" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":R1ccbjnf6:" popovertarget=":R1ccbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-R1ccbjnf6"><a class="SlideshowCardLink_root__p8KI7" data-cy="slideshow-card-link" data-testid="slideshow-card-link" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike/java-journal-pyresso-a-pythonbased-framework-for-debugging-java"><span class="sr-only">Java Journal &amp; Pyresso: A Python-Based Framework for Debugging Java" src="https://cdn.slidesharecdn.com/ss_thumbnails/javajournalpyspresso-160624232225-thumbnail.jpg?width=560&amp;fit=bounds" loading="lazy"/><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_contain__K6M0d" alt="Java Journal &amp; Pyresso: A Python-Based Framework for Debugging Java</span><button type="button" class="Button_root__i1yp0 Button_secondary__hHiHI Button_text__ZT_3O Button_small__sqsEx Button_icon__1C4qi save-slideshow-button SaveButton_root__b6zuu" data-testid="button" aria-checked="false" aria-label="Save Java Journal &amp; Pyresso: A Python-Based Framework for Debugging Java for later" role="switch" aria-haspopup="dialog" aria-controls=":Rbdccbjnf6:" popovertarget=":Rbdccbjnf6:" style="anchor-name:--popover-Rbdccbjnf6"><span class="icon Icon_root__AjZyv" style="--size:24px"><span class="Icon_icon__4zzsG" style="mask-image:url(https://public.slidesharecdn.com/_next/static/media/save.ef1812e2.svg);background-color:currentColor"></span><span class="sr-only"></span></span></button><div class="Tooltip_root__7FS0Y" id=":Rbdccbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="top" style="position-anchor:--popover-Rbdccbjnf6"></div><a class="SlideshowAuthor_root__IkT1_ RailCard_author__JYeYZ slideshow-author ellipsis" data-testid="slideshow-author" data-cy="slideshow-author" href="https://www.slideshare.net/CrowdStrike">CrowdStrike</a><div class="slideshow-stats SlideshowStats_root__EQOR1 RailCard_stats__ZvZms"> </div><span aria-hidden="true" class="seo-only">Despite the multitude of Java decompilers available, we often have the need to debug or trace malicious or obfuscated Java bytecode. Existing Java debuggers and tracers are mostly targeted towards Java developers, are closed-source, and are not meant to handle malicious or obfuscated targets. We present a new open-source cross-platform framework for debugging Java, written completely in Python, designed specifically for reverse engineering. We also present a Java method call tracer as a sample Python application that utilizes this framework.</span></div></div><div class="" id=":R1ccbjnf6:" popover="manual" data-popover-position="bottom-start" style="position-anchor:--popover-R1ccbjnf6"></div><div class="separator Separator_root__70Ime Separator_horizontal__czVEa" href="https://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/crowd-cast-monthly-mitigating-pass-the-hash/26618483"><span class="sr-only">CrowdCasts Monthly: Mitigating Pass the Hash</span></a><div class="slideshow-thumbnail Thumbnail_root__qLW0K SlideshowCard_thumb__86aJk" style="aspect-ratio:1.5;--index:14" data-testid="card-thumbnail"><img class="Thumbnail_thumb__UXO3a Thumbnail_blur__opK6A
